div.head: The Work done in Algiers
div.ab: Have a colt of three of four years & feed it on rye barley & straw pig cut in the manner with which they feed horses in Spain. Let it drink water from a good fountain or river. I do not know if it would be good sometimes to let it drink the water of sulfur springs, & to sometimes give it fenugreek or other hot foods, for the intention of the worker is to use the heat of its manure, & the climate here is cooler than that of Algiers. Keep it in a warm place & use it & it should lose none of its manure & urine, of which you will make a mass or two in order that while one cools the other will be of a heat suitable for continuing. Also have a large long-necked glass bottle as thick as possible, & one finger if it can be so made, & of the capacity of one pitcher or earthen jug. Put into it around St John a dozen & a half chicken eggs, that is to say, the yolk without the glair & the germ. See ) Others say lx yolks. And it will be with this dozen & a half of egg yolks put one half ounce (others say lx eggs & a half pound) of female silkworm eggs. And after luting well the flask (I do not know if air will be needed for the generation there). Put & bury it in the heat of the manure up to the neck, and leave it there until several worms will be engendered. And then remove the long-necked bottle & do not bury it in the manure anymore. But put it on the hot layer of the manure until all the worms will be eaten & consume one another by shriveling and stirring, and only one remains. Once this has happened, you must entice it at regular intervals, day & night, with the assistance of two men, who will care for it in shifts, and you will lure it with an egg yolk covered in gold leaf or with a liquid egg yolk into which the gold leaf has been incorporated. & be careful that it does not miss such fodder (some say one egg yolk per hour, others say three, but the thing itself will demonstrate the practice). Nourished in this way it will grow in two months or seven weeks & will become like a serpent, one span & four fingers long, & one pound in weight. And as the wings will begin to develop, one will need to kill it, doing so with a charcoal fire in a ring around the bottle one span away from it, & at that time lute the bottle well so that it does not exhale.
